title: This Bunny Cake Is So Cute, It'll Be All That Anyone Cares About This Easter
description: Loved by kids and adults alike. READ MORE...
author: Kayla Hoang
excerpt: Loved by kids and adults alike.

Plus, I couple that with a simple frosting whose flavor outruns any of the store-bought stuff. Key Ingredients in Bunny Cake Boxed cake mix: Be sure to use your favorite brand of yellow, white, or vanilla cake mix. Be wary of swapping for chocolate cake mix, as it may peek through the frosting.  Powdered sugar: Feel free to adjust to your taste if you prefer a sweeter frosting.   Pink gel food coloring: Gives you the most bang for your buck. html:
• Recipes
  • Desserts
  • Cakes

The Most Adorable Bunny Cake of All Time

Kayla Hoang

Kayla Hoang is a freelance recipe developer, writer, and baker. She is a graduate of Johnson and Wales University’s 4-year Baking and Pastry program and has training from Alain Ducasse’s Ecole Nationale Supérieure de Pâtisserie in Yssingeaux, France. Her love of food comes from…read more

published about 5 hours ago

Boxed cake mix makes prep a breeze.

Serves12

Prep1 hour

Cook25 minutes

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

When I was first getting into cake decorating, recipes like this bunny cake were exactly what I was most drawn to. I loved a themed cake. Big bonus points if it was easy enough for a not-so-skilled 13-year-old to do. My take on the Easter bunny cake is a delicious treat that’s fun for kids and adults alike. In this recipe, boxed cake mix makes prep a breeze and ultimately leaves more time for the fun stuff — decorating! The vanilla frosting is quick, easy to make, and sweetened just enough to not become cloying when covered in sweetened shredded coconut (read: the bunny’s fur). Jelly beans (plus a little pink frosting) pull double duty, making for the sweetest bunny face and the decoration for its bow tie. A guaranteed crowd-pleaser, this cake is as delicious as it is adorable. 

Why You’ll Love It

  • No special shaped pans needed. All you need are two 8-inch cake pans to make this cute cake. 
  • Using boxed cake mix cuts down on prep time. Plus, I couple that with a simple frosting whose flavor outruns any of the store-bought stuff.

Key Ingredients in Bunny Cake

  • Boxed cake mix: Be sure to use your favorite brand of yellow, white, or vanilla cake mix. Be wary of swapping for chocolate cake mix, as it may peek through the frosting. 
  • Powdered sugar: Feel free to adjust to your taste if you prefer a sweeter frosting.  
  • Pink gel food coloring: Gives you the most bang for your buck. You need just a small drop to tint the frosting a light pink color. 
  • Sweetened shredded coconut: Has a little more flavor than unsweetened coconut and balances the just-sweet-enough frosting. 
  • Jelly beans: Use an assortment of colors to bring the bow tie to life.   

How to Make the Bunny Cake

  1. Bake, cool, and cut the cake. Follow the package directions for baking the cake. When it’s time to cut the cake, you can freehand, but using a stencil is helpful in making sure you like the shape of the bow tie and ears before cutting (and potentially messing up) the actual cake. 
  2. Make the frosting. Be sure to use room-temperature butter to yield a lump-free, extra-fluffy frosting. 
  3. Assemble and decorate. No need to worry about getting the white frosting perfectly smooth, as the shredded coconut will cover any imperfections. 

Helpful Swaps

  • Two (16-ounce) cans of vanilla frosting can be used in place of the homemade frosting. 
  • Red liquid food coloring can be used in place of pink gel food coloring. 

Storage and Make-Ahead Tips

  • Leftover cake can be stored tightly covered at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. 
  • The cakes can be made up to a day ahead of assembling. Tightly wrap the cooled cakes with plastic wrap and store at room temperature until ready to use. 

More Easter Desserts

Comments

Boxed cake mix makes prep a breeze.

Nutritional Info

Ingredients

For the cake:

  • Cooking spray

  • 1 (15.25-ounce) box

    yellow, white, or vanilla cake mix

  • Water, eggs, and oil needed for cake mix (see package directions)

For the frosting (or substitute with 2 [16-ounce] cans vanilla frosting):

  • 2 1/2 sticks (10 ounces)

    unsalted butter, at room temperature

  • 2 cups

    powdered sugar

  • 1 1/2 teaspoons

    vanilla extract

  • 1/8 teaspoon

    kosher salt

  • 3 tablespoons

    cold heavy cream or milk

  • Pink gel or red liquid food coloring

For decorating:

  • 2 cups

    sweetened shredded coconut (about 5 3/4 ounces)

  • 2

    black or dark purple jelly beans, for the eyes

  • 1

    pink jelly bean, for the nose

  • About 1/4 cup

    assorted jelly beans, for the bow tie

Make the cake:

  1. Heat the oven according to cake package directions. Coat 2 (8-inch) round cake pans with cooking spray. Line the bottom of each with a parchment paper round.

  2. Prepare 1 (15.25-ounce) box cake mix by mixing in the water, eggs, and oil according to package directions. Divide the batter between the cake pans.

  3. Bake according to package directions for an 8-inch cake. Let cool slightly, about 10 minutes. Flip the cakes out of the pan onto a wire rack, remove the parchment, and let cool completely. Meanwhile, make the frosting.

Make the frosting:

  1. Beat 2 1/2 sticks room-temperature unsalted butter, 2 cups powdered sugar, 1 1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract, and 1/8 teaspoon kosher salt with the paddle attachment in a stand mixer on low speed, scraping the bowl halfway through, until just combined and there are no more dry spots, about 1 minute total.

  2. Increase the speed to medium and beat until smooth and lightened in color, scraping the bowl as needed, about 2 minutes. Beat in 3 tablespoons cold heavy cream on medium-high speed until fluffy, 2 to 4 minutes more.

  3. Transfer 1 cup of the frosting to a small bowl. Stir in pink gel food coloring until the desired color is reached. Transfer the pink frosting to a piping bag or small resealable plastic bag with a bottom corner snipped off.

Assemble and decorate:

  1. Cut out an 8-inch parchment paper round. Fold the round in half. Place on an upside-down 8-inch round cake pan, lining it up with the left side of the pan. Mark the paper 2 1/2 inches in from the center of the rounded edge. Slide the paper to the right side of the pan, lining up the marking with the right edge. Trace the right rounded edge onto the paper. With the paper still folded, cut off the traced portion and unfold the paper. You should have two oblong, football shapes (the ears) and a bow tie shape.

  2. Place 1 of the cooled cakes on a cutting board. Place the bow tie stencil over the center, lining up the curved edges. Cut, following the stencil as a guide, to create the two ears and the bow tie.

  3. Place the second cake on a serving platter and arrange the ears on top to create the bunny head. Make sure to leave enough room under the head for the bow tie to be added later.

  4. Frost the top and sides of the head and ears with the white frosting. Pipe some of the pink frosting on the center of the ears and use a spatula to spread into an even layer.

  5. Press 2 cups sweetened shredded coconut onto the bunny head and on the edges of the ears, leaving the pink centers of the ears exposed.

  6. Arrange 2 black jelly beans and 1 pink jelly bean to make the eyes and nose. Use the pink frosting to pipe whiskers and a mouth.

  7. Nestle the bow tie-shaped piece of cake against the bunny’s chin. Frost the bow tie with the remaining pink frosting. Arrange about 1/4 assorted jelly beans to outline the bow tie.

Recipe Notes

Substitutions: 2 (16-ounce) cans vanilla frosting can be used in place of the homemade frosting.

Ingredient/equipment variations: A piping bag fitted with a small round tip will help you pipe cleaner lines for the mouth and whiskers, but isn’t necessary.

Make ahead: The cakes can be made up to 1 day ahead of assembling. Tightly wrap with plastic wrap and store at room temperature.

Storage: Leftover cake can be stored tightly covered at room temperature for up to 1 day or in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.
